Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Their teacher invited them to summarize key teachings for a temple session tomorrow.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my older sister: “Don’t forget, we’re all meeting at Grandma’s for the holiday dinner tonight. It means a lot to Mom.” I could almost hear her voice, warm but insistent, reminding me how much these gatherings matter to our family. I glanced at the stack of Buddhist texts on my desk, the ones my teacher had asked me to summarize for tomorrow’s temple session. He’d said, “Your insights will help guide the group’s reflection. Please take your time with it.” I felt the weight of both requests pressing in on me. My family expected me to be present, to laugh and share stories, to be a good sibling. But my teacher and my sangha were counting on me to prepare, to be thoughtful and thorough, to honor my commitment as a Buddhist practitioner. I stared at the clock, feeling the hours slip away, torn between the warmth of my family and the quiet call of my spiritual path, unsure which part of myself I would have to disappoint.
